title: Question 1 - 6.2.7
text: The function `f(x) = 20tan(pi 10x)` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `x`, in seconds, and distance `f(x)`, in feet. Evaluate `f(1)` and `f(2.5)` and discuss the function’s values at those inputs.
options: `f(1)=0` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `1`, in seconds and `f(2.5)=0` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `2.5`, in seconds.

`f(1)=12.967` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `1`, in seconds and `f(2.5)-2.671` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `2.5`, in seconds.

`f(1)=0` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `1`, in seconds and `f(2.5)=6.667 * 10^(-13)` marks the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall for time `2.5`, in seconds.

`f(1)=`undefined means the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall cannot be calculated at `1` second `f(2.5)=`undefined means the distance in the movement of a light beam from a police car across a wall cannot be calculated at `2.5` seconds

title: Question 2 - 6.2.7
text: Standing on the shore of a lake, a fisherman sights a boat far in the distance to his left. Let `x`, measured in radians, be the angle formed by the line of sight to the ship and a line due north from his position. Assume due north is 0 and 𝑥 is measured negative to the left and positive to the right. (See Figure 19) The boat travels from due west to due east and, ignoring the curvature of the Earth, the distance `d(x)`, in kilometers, from the fisherman to the boat is given by the function `d(x)=1.5sec(x)`. (a) What is a reasonable domain for `d(x)`? (b) Find and discuss the meaning of any vertical asymptotes on the graph of `d(x)`. (c) Calculate and interpret `d(−pi/3)`. Round to the second decimal place.(d) Calculate and interpret `d(pi/6)`.Round to the second decimal place.(e) What is the minimum distance between the fisherman and the boat? When does this occur?
options: a) `(-pi/2, pi/2)`, b) `x= -pi/2` and `x=pi/2`; the distance grows without bound as `abs(x)` approaches `pi/2` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c) `3` km; when `x = -pi/3` the fisherman is `3` km to the west of the boat. d) `1.73` km; when `x = pi/6` the boat is `1.73` km away. e) `1.5` km when `x=0`.

a) `(-pi/2, (3pi)/2)` b) `x= -pi/2` and `x= (3pi)/2`; the distance grows without bound as approaches `(3pi)/2` or `-pi/2` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c) `30` km; when `x= -pi/3` the fisherman is `30` km away from the boat. d) `2` km; when `x=pi/6` the boat is `2` km away. e) `2` km; when `x= pi/6`.

a) `(-pi, pi)` b) `x= -pi` and `x= pi`; the distance grows without bound as `abs(x)` approaches `pi` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c)  `1.5` km; when `x= -pi/3` the fisherman is `1.5` km away from the boat. d) `1.5` km; when `x= pi/6` the boat is `1.5` km away. e) `1.5` km when `x=-pi/3` and `x= pi/6`

a) `(-2pi, 2pi)` b) `x= -2pi` and `x= 2pi`; the distance grows without bound as `abs(x)` approaches `2pi` i.e. at right angles to the line representing due north the boat would be so far away the fisherman could not see the other boat. c)  `3` km; when `x= -pi/3` the fisherman is `3` km away from the boat. d) `0` km; when `x=2pi` the boat is `0` km away. e) `0` km; when `x=2pi`

title: Question 3 - 6.2.7
text: A laser rangefinder is locked on a comet approaching Earth. The distance `g(x)`, in kilometers, of the comet after `x` days, for `x` in the interval `0` to `30` days, is given by `g(x)= 250,000 csc(pi/(30) x)`. Evaluate `g(5)` and interpret the information.
options: `g(5)=500,000`. The comet is `500,000` kilometers from the Earth after `5` days.
`g(5)= undefined`. The comet is too far away for the rangefinder to find it after `5` days.
`g(5)=0`. The comet hits the Earth after `5` days.
`g(5)=500`. The comet is `500` kilometers from the Earth after `5` days.

title: Question 4 - 6.2.7
text: A video camera is focused on a rocket on a launching pad `2` miles from the camera. The angle of elevation from the ground to the rocket after `x` seconds `pi 120x`. a) Write a function expressing the altitude `h(x)`, in miles, of the rocket above the ground after `x` seconds. Ignore the curvature of the Earth. b) Evaluate and interpret the values `h(0)` and `h(30)`. c) What happens to the values of `h(x)` as `x` approaches `60` seconds? Interpret the meaning of this in terms of the problem.
options: a) `h(x) = 2tan(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=0` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is `0` miles above the ground or in other words, the rocket launches from ground level; `h(30)=2` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `2` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` grow infinitely large. The distance to the rocket is growing so large that the camera can no longer track it.

a) `h(x) = 2cos(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=2` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is `2` miles above the ground; `h(30)=1.41` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `1.41` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` decrease as the rocket comes back to Earth.

a) `h(x) = 2csc(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=undefined` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is too far away to be tracked by the camera; `h(30)=3` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `3` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` decrease as the rocket comes back to Earth.

a) `h(x) = 2sec(pi/120 x)` b) `h(0)=2` which means that after `0` seconds, the rocket is `2` miles above the ground; `h(30)=2.82` means that after `30` seconds the rocket is `2.82` miles above the ground. c) As `x` approaches `60` seconds, the values of `h(x)` grow increasingly large. The distance to the rocket is growing so large that the camera can no longer track it.
